loans.name: Benedicto's Group

texts.en:
Benedicto M. is a 62-year-old, hardworking man. He is married with 11 children, three of whom are still in school as he also takes care of three grandchildren and one orphan. Benedicto has had multiple businesses -- poultry, bricklaying and the sale of produce -- in Kitega for 29 years. His major business challenges are the changes in prices depending on the season. He is able to make about 200,000 Ugandan shillings in profits a week and that helps him in taking care of his family and saving for future developments. His dream is to spread his business to other areas apart from his village as well as to build rental houses for monthly earnings.

Benedicto needs a loan to help buy more feed for his chicken as well as more produce for resale, since loans have boosted his businesses.

loans.use: Buying more chicken feed and more produce for resale

loans.name: Beverly

texts.en:
Mrs. Beverly P. enjoys taking care of her rice farm. She is 45 years old, married and has two children. She said that her business is very helpful to her family. It provides their daily needs and enables her to pay her bills.

Beverly’s farm currently needs additional farm supplies like fertilizers. She applied for a loan from the Kiva field partner, CEVI, in the amount of 15,000 PHP. Receiving this loan will be truly helpful to Beverly as she works to have an abundant harvest.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Wonders Of God Group

texts.en: Grace is forty eight years old. She is widowed and has four children who are all in school. She lives with her children in a rented apartment in Axim. Axim is along the coastal area in the western region of Ghana. Fishing is the major occupation of the people. Grace is a food vendor. She is the leader of a trust bank group called Wonders of God. The members of the group are mainly traders. The group requests a loan to procure goods in bulk to expand their businesses. It is their desire to give their children the best education they can afford.

loans.use: To buy stock

loans.name: Kiden

texts.en:
Kiden R. is currently in the business of brewing and selling locally made liquor beverages from her home and is requesting a loan to stock more materials to use and crates of beer to sell.  Kiden is 30 years old and married. Her husband is a soldier. She has 4 children who attend school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open a hotel.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: stock more materials to use and crates of beer to sell.

loans.name: Nguyễn Thị's Group
loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Rosalia's Group

texts.en:
Rosalia T. is from Barangay Lawig in the municipality of Lamut, province Ifugao. She is 46 years old and serves as the leader for this 11-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Rosalia T. Group.

Rosalia is married and has 2 school-aged children. Rosalia owns a general store where she sells daily use products like shampoo, soap, and toothpaste. Rosalia has been in business for over 3 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month.

Rosalia joined ASKI last year to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rosalia has successfully repaid a 5,000 PHP loan from ASKI, which she used to purchase additional goods for her store. Rosalia is now requesting her second loan, in the amount of 7000 PHP, so she can buy new items for her store. She hopes to earn additional revenue so she can improve the living conditions of her family. 

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items for her shop.

loans.name: Rin

texts.en:
Mrs. Rin R. is 31 years old and married, with four school-aged kids who are dependent on her. For the past fifteen years, she has been planting crops in the village. In the business, she grows crops like rice and local vegetables. As another source of family income, her husband makes a daily revenue by working as a medical doctor. He usually goes to examine patients who are his nearby neighbors. 

Presently he doesn’t have enough medical supplies to furnish an examination room for his work. Therefore, Rin R. has requested a loan for her husband to purchase the required articles. (Rin R. was busy working on the farm when the photo taken, so her husband is shown instead.)

loans.use: To buy medical supplies

loans.name: Roxana

texts.en:
Roxana, the owner of Sweet Voices Daycare Center, has a clear vision for the future of her business and the determination and experience to back it up. After working at a pre-school for ten years, Roxana enrolled herself in classes through a community resource center that focused specifically on how to start a daycare. In 2003, armed with grant funding and her childcare certificate, Roxana opened her own in-home daycare business.

Since starting her own daycare seven years ago, Roxana has continued to take child development classes in order to integrate new learning programs into her work with the children she cares for. The classes, she explains, complement a natural affinity for her chosen career. “God has given me the patience and wisdom I need for this job. Child development taught me about the character of each child. They respect me, and I respect them. I love this work; it is my calling.”

A loan of $5,000 will pay for two computers (one to help Roxana manage her business and the other with learning software for the children) as well as a desk, new games, and safety improvements to the patio for outside activities. “I’m not content to stay where I am. I want to keep growing, I want to accomplish more. And when I want to do something, nothing can get in my way.”

loans.use: To buy two computers, computer software, furniture, safety equipment and games

loans.name: Rufo

texts.en:
Rufo P. is 42 and married with 6 children (ages 6 - 18).  She owns a business venture, planting & harvesting taro for sale.  Rufo has 3 years of experience in this business.  Rufo needs a loan of WST $1500 to purchase weed-killers such as Gramoxome.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 450 talas or US $188 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2008, Rufo joined SPBD.  This is her 2nd loan with SPBD. SPBD's loans are Rufo's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

The following social metrics for Rufo P. are provided by SPBD*:
Overall Social Metric Score:                1.5 out of 3
Level of Education:                              1.4 out of 3
Level of total Household Income:         1.3 out of 3
Quality of Household Assets:              1.5 out of 3

*SPBD measures the living conditions of each of its borrowers to track her loan progress. The overall social metric score, provided by SPBD, is based upon a number of factors, such as the condition of the house/household assets, health, education, income level, and family reputation. A higher number represents a higher score. For example, a ""3 out of 3"" on education would mean that the borrower has graduated from university; a ""2 out of 3"" = secondary/high-school, and a ""1 out of 3"" would mean that the borrower is uneducated.

For more information on this score, please see SPBD's partner page at: http://partners.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=15

About SPBD
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.

Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD: http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

loans.use: to purchase weed-killers such as Gramoxome

loans.name: Virgen De Copacabana Group

texts.es:
La alcancía Comunal Virgen D. Copacabana se caracteriza por ser solidaria y responsable en sus pagos.
Hilaria es la presidenta del grupo hace varios años se dedica al comercio viendo la necesidad D. apoyar a su esposo con los gastos D. su hogar comenzó a vender ropa, y otros productos ahora solo se dedica a la venta D. queso, los fines D. semana viaja a un lugar D. Lima que se llama Huarochiri y allí es donD. compra el queso, para sus exigentes clientes, este negocio que le ha brindado algunas satisfacciones ya que pueD. conocer este lugar y buscar precios más bajos para tener mayores ganancias.
El tesorero Jorge se dedica a la venta D. tubérculos, en un mercado D. Huaycan vive hace 13 años, ello le permite mantener a sus 3 hijos que aun están en la etapa escolar, Jorge está contento con el préstamo y es muy responsable y exigente con el grupo.
Edith es una socia que con mucho esfuerzo compro su mototaxi con la ayuda D. su esposo, pero como tiene que dedicar tiempo a su pequeña hija, alquila el mototaxi a una persona D. confianza. Ella trabaja con el mototaxi haciendo servicio D. transporte público los fines D. semana así pueD. tener más ingresos para su casa.
Todo el grupo agradece los préstamos recibidos por KIVA y EDAPROSPO
texts.en:
The “Virgen D. Copacabana” (Our Lady of Copacabana) communal bank is united and responsible with respect to its loan repayments. Hilaria is the group president and has been a merchant for several years because she needs to help her husband meet household expenses. She started out selling clothing and other products; now, she only sells cheese. On weekends, she goes to a part of Lima known as Huarochiri to buy the cheese for her discerning customers. This business has been very satisfying for her in that she has been able to get to know this place and look for better prices so that she can earn higher profits. The group treasurer is Jorge. He sells tubers in one of Huaycan’s markets. He has been in this line of work for 13 years and it has allowed him to support his three children, who are still school-aged. Jorge is happy with the loan and is very responsible and strict with the group. Edith is a member who, with much effort and with help from her husband, was able to purchase a mototaxi (three-wheel vehicle used to transport passengers and cargo). Because she must care for her young daughter, she leases the mototaxi to a trustworthy person. She provides public transportation services during weekends to earn extra income for her home. The entire group appreciates the loans granted by KIVA and EDAPROSPO.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy merchandise.

loans.name: Bonifacia

texts.en:
Bonifacia M. has been dedicated since she was very young to engage in a hog-fattening business. Presently, she relies on this activity to cover her personal costs and to help sustain her family.

Bonifacia buys piglets from her neighbors, raises them, and when they have reached a good point of development, she sells them to business people who visit the village. This activity is very common in their location and many entrepreneurs do this.

Bonifacia wishes to expand her business by buying more piglets, vitamins and feed, in order to forge ahead with her business and be able to help her family to get ahead. For this reason, she is for the first time requesting a Kiva loan of 20,000 Php through ASHI to help her reach her goal.

Bonifacia is a hardworking woman who is dedicated to her home. Her dream is to care for her three children and offer them a better quality of life. Her neighbors, friends, and even her group mates consider her an agreeable and respectful person.

Bonifacia’s dreams are to provide a better future for her family, to sustain the profitability of her business, and to start a savings account for her children and support them in finishing their studies until they complete college and find good jobs.

Through hard work and determination, Bonifacia is focused on improving her quality of life through her entrepreneurial initiatives with support from ASHI and Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy more piglets, vitamins and pig feed

loans.name: Carolina's Group

texts.en: Carolina O. is from the village of Brgy. Sampauita, Solano, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 59 years old. Carolina is the group leader of a five-member group loan offered by ASKI, a Kiva partner. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. Carolina is married and has four adult children. To make a living, Carolina runs a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. Carolina has been engaged in her business for over eight years and earns approximately 6,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities. In 2009, Carolina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Carolina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Carolina is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This will be the second loan taken out by Carolina from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Nelly

texts.en:
Nelly C. is from the town of Banga. She is 55 years old. Nelly is married and has 3 adult children. To make a living Nelly raises crops. Her main source of income comes from planting and harvesting rice to sell. Nelly has been engaged in her business for over 10 years already.

Nelly joined CEVI to improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid previous loans from CEVI. Nelly is requesting her 8th loan, for 15000 PHP, which she will use to purchase fertilizers such as manure and other farm inputs. She plans to use the additional revenue to supplement her family's income.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure and other farm inputs.

loans.name: Srey

texts.en:
Srey D., 60, is married and lives with her husband and two children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for its palm products. Her husband appears in the photograph.

D. produces clay products for an income of USD 3 per day. Her husband raises pigs, earning an income of about USD 1 per day. D. is requesting a loan of USD 100 to purchase more pig feed for her husband’s pigs.

In the future, D. would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy more pig feed

loans.name: May God Bless Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are members of the “May God Bless” group from Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. They are small-business women who have come to SMT, a partner of Kiva, in order to seek a loan of SLL 800,000 each. With this loan, they will be able to add more goods to their businesses, attract more customers, make more sales and profits and consequently improve on their living conditions.

The leader of this group of entrepreneurs is Ramatu K. who was born in Makoth village, 46 years ago. She is married and has five children. Her husband is a businessman and one of her children is in secondary school.

Ramatu sells palm-oil (the most popular cooking oil in the country), groundnuts (peanuts) and rice. She has been a businesswoman for many years. She will use this loan to buy gallons of palm-oil, bags of groundnuts, and bags of rice.

loans.use: To buy gallons of palm-oil, bags of groundnuts, and bags of rice

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda N. is from the village of Eastern, Wao, Lanao del Sur. She is 59 years old. Erlinda is married and has 5 adult-aged children. To make a living, Erlinda owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food & daily use products and also having a mini-eatery in the local community. Erlinda has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 3500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Erlinda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Erlinda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Erlinda is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Erlinda from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the borrower's business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory & working capital for her "sari-sari" store

loans.name: Roselyn

texts.en:
Roselyn F. is from the village of Pagahan, Initao, Misamis Oriental. She is 22 years old, single and has 1 infant. Roselyn owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling seafood products, including fish and shrimp, in the local community. Roselyn has been engaged in her business for over 1 year and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month from it.

In 2010, Roselyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Roselyn is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional fish to sell. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Roselyn from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional fish to sell

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more used clothes.

loans.name: Marijane

texts.en:
Marijane S. is from the city of Dipolog. She is 30 years old. Marijane is married and has 2 infant-aged children. To make a living, Marijane owns and operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, and toothpaste in the local community. Marijane has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately PHP5,000 a month for these activities.

In 2010, Marijane joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marijnae is requesting a new loan of PHP12,000, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Marijane from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

location.town: Dipolog-Tabuk Tulay, Dipolog City, Zamboanga del N

loans.name: Ania Lucrecia

texts.es:
Ania es una pequeña comerciante, que ha venido creciendo gracias a su tenacidad y empeño al negocio una pulpería que comenzó con liquidación de su trabajo anterior. Y con el apoyo de su esposo, siendo policía.
Aun no tiene casa, alquila y ese es su proyecto que tiene tener una casa propia.
Afodenic ha aportado para que su negocio crezca y está contenta porque está logrando el objetivo de crecer como comerciante.
Comprara: Granos básicos, lácteos, carne, pollo, golosinas, para aumentar el inventario y mejorar las ventas e ir ahorrando.
texts.en:
Ania is a small businesswoman who, thanks to her tenacity and determination, has been growing her pulpería [small grocery store] business. With the help of her husband, a policeman, she started the pulpería when her previous job was eliminated. She does not have a house, as she is a renter, but her goal is to have her own house. AFODENIC has supported her so that her business could grow, and she is happy because she is achieving her goal of growing as a businesswoman. She will buy: basic grains, dairy products, meat, chicken, and candies, in order to increase her inventory, improve her sales, and continue saving.

Translated from Spanish by Katie Kavanagh, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to purchase basic grains, dairy products, meat, chicken, and candy (to improve sales)

loans.name: Maritza Delida

texts.es:
Maritza Delida T. E. tiene 35 anos. Es soltera y vive en el cantón de Chillanes en la Provincia Bolívar. Tiene 2 hijos de 3 y 11 anos. 

Maritza es una socia de la ventanilla rural Progreso Comunitario, que está ubicada a dos horas de Chillanes. Son 11 socios en total, que en la mayoridad se dedican al cultivo de cacao o tienen sus propios pequeños negocios.  

Maritza es agricultura, cultiva cacao. Compra sus productos en Babahoyo y se venden en Mata de Cacao cada 15 dias o al mes. Con el apoyo del préstamo podria mejorar sus cultivos para que sean mas productivos, y tambien ponerles abonos. 

Su sueno es salir del pueblo y darles una buena educación a sus hijos. Tambien le gustaria comprar una casa en vez de arrentar. Se desafia por la lluvia que se quema el cacao (el cacao se pone un color negro). Tambien dice que es difícil cuidar a sus hijos sola. 

En su tiempo libre, se dedica a sus hijos y les ayuda en sus tareas.
texts.en:
Maritza Delida T. E. is 35 years old. She is single and lives in the canton of Chillanes, in Bolívar province. She has two children, aged 3 and 11. 

Maritza is a member of the "Progreso Comunitario" ["Community Progress"] solidarity group, which is located two hours from Chillanes. It has a total of 11 members, most of whom work growing cacao or have their own small businesses.  

Maritza is a farmer who grows cacao [cocoa]. She buys her supplies in Babahoyo and sells her products in Mata de Cacao once every 15 days or once a month. With the help of the loan, she will be able to improve her crops so that they are more productive, and she will also be able to fertilize them. 

Her dream is to leave the village and provide a good education to her children. She would also like to buy a house instead of renting. One of her challenges is the rain that burns the cacao (the cacao turns a black color). She also says that it is difficult to take care of her children alone. 

In her free time, she takes care of her children and helps them with their homework.

loans.use: Buying supplies for cacao cultivation

loans.name: Maria Cristina

texts.en: Maria Cristina L. is from the village of Guinatan. She is 41 years old. Maria Cristina is single. To make a living, Maria Cristina sells clothing and shoe products in the local community. Maria Cristina has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 6,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2009, Maria Cristina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Maria Cristina has successfully repaid a previous loan from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Maria Cristina is requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP, which will also be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Maria Cristina from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to expand his business and buy some essential tools

loans.name: Keo

texts.en: Keo S., 43, is married and lives with her five children in Takeo province. She is a farmer who works for less than US$1 each day, while her husband works in construction making US$3 each day. The weather conditions have been difficult for farming in Cambodia this past year and inflation has caused food prices to skyrocket. These factors have played into a difficult economic year for many Cambodians, Keo S. included. Two of her children are garment factory workers and three are in school. Keo S. is asking for a loan of US$600 to purchase a motorbike for her children to commute to work.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike.

loans.name: Cresbee

texts.en:
Cresbee P. is from the village of Baylao, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 23 years old. Cresbee is married and has 2 infant children. To make a living, Cresbee owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop.  The main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, canned goods & junk foods in the local community. Cresbee has been engaged in her business for over 1 year and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Cresbee joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Cresbee has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to buy and sell. Cresbee is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Cresbee from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory & working capital

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence N. lives in the Mengo Mackay neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has 4 children, 3 of whom are in school.  Florence has a business of a retail shop.  She has been in this business for 6 years, and she works 7 days out of every week.  Florence sells her products from home by means of retail.  

Florence has requested a loan of 500000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bags of sugar, cartons of salt, boxes of soap, and cooking oil.  The main business challenges for Florence  include thieves and competition.  Her goals and aspirations are to start selling wholesale only and to educate her children up to university. 

Florence lives in a home that she rents.  She has access to electricity but doesn't have access to piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include rent, food, school fees, and medication.

loans.use: To buy sugar, salt, soap, cooking oil

loans.name: Uuganbayar

texts.en:
Uuganbayar B. is 22 years old and lives with his wife and 2-year-old son in a rented apartment Uvurhangai province of Mongolia. He owns a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent and yard. He has been an orphan since he was child and has been working very hard to support and raise his two siblings. His wife is currently unemployed and stays at home taking care of their son. 

Uuganbayar operates a cellphone repair service, that he started in 2006, in his town. Since 2009, he has continued operating a cellphone repair service shop in a rented space at the local market after completing a cellphone parts and repair training course. Uuganbayar hopes to expand his business by selling cellphones in addition to his repair service in the future. Uuganbayar is a self confident and optimistic man. He is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to purchase more cellphone parts and tools for his cellphone repair shop.

loans.use: To purchase more cellphone parts and tools.

loans.name: Flor Del Sol 1 & 2 Group

texts.en:
Christella lives with her only child in a small rural town in the Dominican Republic. She runs a small business selling new clothes and shoes from her home, and occasionally she sells her merchandise on the streets of her community. She has been in this business for a year. Starting with some savings, she decided to invest in clothing sales because this is the kind of merchandise most people need.

Christella began her association with Esperanza International Dominican Republic because she was in need of capital, as were her group members and their families. Her story is representative generally of her group and of Esperanza's Dominican and Haitian clients, many of whom recently emigrated to the Dominican Republic from Haiti. Her group is located in the town of Hato Mayor whose economy depends on farming. It is one of the most rural towns in the Dominican Republic. In this town, as in many others, there is a population of Dominicans and Haitian emigrants as well as a scarcity of potable water and electricity.

Christella is requesting a loan to buy a better selection of clothes and shoes to sell. It is her goal to own her own store where she can offer more variety in her merchandise. Christella is excited to be taking her first loan with Esperanza. She hopes to provide for herself and her child while doing business and, within a few years, save up enough to buy her own home.

loans.use: To buy clothes and shoes to sell

loans.name: Mejumaa

texts.en:
Mejumaa is a married woman with three children, all of whom attend school. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For over ten years, she has operated a tailoring business from home. Her customers are neighbors, especially ladies. Mejumaa faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. During the holiday season, the demand for clothes is high, while during the months of January to July, the demand is lower. She hopes to establish a dressmaking school in the future.

With the Kshs 30,000 she wants to purchase cloth materials and a sewing machine for her tailoring business. She decided to join Yehu because of its good customer relations.

loans.use: To purchase cloth materials and a sewing machine for her tailoring business.

loans.name: Patrick

texts.en:
Patrick is a married man with seven children, all of whom attend school. He owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. His greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. 

He has been operating a bicycle repairs shop for the last ten years.  His potential customers are local neighbours. Patrick faces a major challenge in delayed payments by debtors and the high cost of transportation. He hopes to become a dealer of motorcycle spare parts and sell as a wholesaler in the future.

With the Kshs 30,000 loan, he wants to purchase bicycle spare parts, tires, brake hoods, spokes and chain wheels. He decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost his business.

loans.use: To purchase bicycle parts

loans.name: Mylaluna

texts.en:
Mylaluna is a married woman who lives in Cadiz, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating a fish vending business. Her husband Willy, who is 44 years old, works as a fish vendor to earn his living and helps in his wife's business activities. They have four children who are 15 to 23 years old. One of the children has their own family and two are currently going to school. Mylaluna joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1999 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 23 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Mylaluna has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 29,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 8,000,  uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 24th loan, she is borrowing PHP 29,500 for additional capital for her fish vending business so that she can continue to save up for future house improvements & the education of her children. Mylaluna is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by joining the NWTF Kiva lending team at http://www.kiva.org

loans.use: Additional capital for fish vending

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en: Evelyn is 38 years old married with 4 children, and her husband is a farmer living in Hioma, Uganda. She has been running a hotel business for 5 years and started it after selling her farm surplus produce. She dreams of owning a popular hotel in town and educating her children. Evelyn needs the loan to pay school fees.

loans.use: Paying school fees.

loans.name: Joey

texts.en:
Joey works hard to support her family. Joey is married and has a ready to wear (clothing) business in the Philippines.

Joey requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to buy more products.

Joey has been in this business for two years now, and also earns additional income from frozen goods vending.

In the future, Joey would like to expand her business, to send her kids to school, and to have savings for her family.

loans.use: to purchase more clothing products to sell

loans.name: Liezel

texts.en:
Liezel is 40 years old.  She is married and has 5 children.

Liezel works hard to provide for her family. She owns a sari-sari store in the Philippines and has been running it for 10 years.  She also earns additional income from food vending.  

Liezel has requested a PHP 11,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional items such as canned goods and noodles to sell in her sari-sari store.  She has borrowed and repaid 4 previous loans from NWTF.

Liezel aspires to improve her sari-sari store business so that she can send her all her children to college.

loans.use: To buy additional items for her sari-sari store

loans.name: Gloria Del Carmen

texts.es:
Desde Hace 10 años la hija de Gloria decidió montar una papelería con ayuda de su madre, para así mejorar la economía de su casa y generar ingresos mientras ella estaba en la universidad, sin embargo los horarios no le permitían estar pendiente del negocio por lo que su madre, Gloria del Carmen P. se apropió del negocio para hacerlo crecer y poco a poco e ir generando más ingresos para su familia, con el fin de mejorar su calidad de vida y aportar a los gastos del hogar y a cubrir los altos costos de la Universidad en la que continuaba estudiando su hija.

Si bien es cierto que una papelería es un buen negocio, Gloria es consciente que en temporada de vacaciones sus ventas son muy pocas, por lo que a medida del tiempo ha incrementado la variedad de productos, actualmente vende también, accesorios de dama, dulces, helados y un poco de ropa. 

Su propósito es poder comprar calzado y poco a poco seguir creciendo pues también espera generar empleo y así aportar a la comunidad, sin embargo, el capital es mucho para ella ya que no posee la cantidad necesaria y por ello necesita de un préstamo.
texts.en:
Ten years ago, Gloria’s daughter decided to open a paper goods store, with the help of her mother, in order to improve the financial situation in her home, and generate an income while she was in university.  Never the less, the schedules did not allow her to attend to her business, so her mother, Gloria del Carmen P., appropriated the business in order to grow it little by little, and to generate more income for the family.  She wanted to improve the family’s quality of life, pay the household expenses, and cover the high cost of her daughter’s university tuition.

It turns out that a paper goods store is a good business.  Gloria is aware that sales are low during vacation times, and so she has increased the variety of products.  Now she also sells ladies’ accessories, candy, ice cream, and some clothing.

She wants to begin buying shoes in order to grow her business a little at a time.  She also hopes to create some jobs and in this way support the community.  Never the less she does not have enough working capital, so she needs this loan.

loans.use: to buy shoes to grow her business

loans.name: Sully

texts.es: Sully casada, su esposo es comerciante, tiene un hijo está estudiando, mujer emprendedora tiene un comedor desde hace un tiempo lo inicio con ayuda de su suegra ahora lo tiene ella, requiere mejorar las condiciones del local para ofrecerles mayores comodidad, el préstamo será invertido en la compra de materia prima como: arroz, frijoles, aceite, sal, mantequillas, carne de res, pollo y cerdo, verduras y otros productos.  Agradece a la financiera por su apoyo al desarrollo de su familia.
texts.en: Sully is married and her husband is a merchant. One of her sons is studying. She is an enterprising woman who has had her restaurant for some time. She started out with the help of her mother-in-law. She needs to recondition her store to provide her clients with greater comfort. The loan will be invested in the purchase of ingredients such as: rice, beans, cooking oil, salt, butter, beef, chicken, and pork, vegetables and other products. She is thankful to the organization for the support received for the development of her family.

loans.use: to purchase ingredients for her restaurant business.

loans.name: Sanumaya

texts.en:
Sanumaya is 45 year old and married, with two children who are 16 and 20 years old.  In 2001, she established her grocery business.  She supoorts her family by working seven days a week and 10 hours a day.  

Sanumaya has already received and successfully repaid five loans from Kiva partner Patan BPW.  She will use the current loan to buy grocery goods for her business.  In the future, Sanumaya plans to improve her family's economic condition.  She thanks you for your support.  

About pasal, small groceries in Nepal:

In the Kathmandu Valley, small grocery stores, called pasal, are an important part of the local economy.  Fresh produce, milk, and staples such as rice, lentils, and flour are purchased daily for cooking in the home.  Owners of small grocery stores use Kiva loans to increase their purchasing power and profit margains.  By keeping inventory strong and purchasing in larger amounts, owners of these small stores are able to increase profitability.  While a typical pasal might be no more than 100 sq. feet, they are always full of bargaining customers, incoming produce, and shrewd businesswomen.

loans.use: to buy grocery goods for her shop

loans.name: Alejandro

texts.es:
Alejandro de 60 años de edad, es padre de familia de 3 hijos independientes, tiene su casa propia, cuenta con  servicio de agua y luz,  en el distrito de Guadalupe que pertenece al departamento de la Libertad. Esta zona se caracteriza por la actividad agricola, ganadera y turismo (zona arqueológica).

Alejandro se dedica  a la crianza y venta de animales (borregos, chivos y otros) desde hace varios años, su corral es apropiado y espaciosos donde se encuentran sus ovejas está en la parte posterior de su casa, los cría con alimentos balanceados como con pastos naturales  y una vez que tengan el peso y el tamaño ideal las ofrece en los diferentes mercados de la zona, con el dinero que va adquirir por la venta sus animales podrá atender sus necesidades personales.  También brinda el servicio de preparación de comida para todo tipo de eventos.

Ha solicitado un préstamo a Edpyme Alternativa de 2000 nuevos soles para la compra de más animales, su respectivo alimento y utensilios para la preparación de su comida cuando solicitan sus servicios.  Alejandro es conocido en la zona por el buen servicio que presta a sus clientes, es una persona trabajadora y dedicada que con mucho esfuerzo y trabajo a sabido salir adelante.
texts.en:
Alejandro is 60 years old and the father of three children who are independent. He lives in his own house and receives water and electricity services. Alejandro resides in the District of Guadalupe, which is part of the Department of La Libertad. This area is known for having businesses that involve farming, livestock breeding, and tourism (with an emphasis on archaeological sites).

Alejandro has been raising and selling animals, such as sheep, goats, and other forms of livestock, for several years. He has the appropriate type of animal pens with enough space for keeping the sheep. The pens are located behind his house. He provides the animals balanced feed, such as natural grasses. Once the animals have reached the ideal size and weight, he offers them for sale at different markets in the area. With the money he earns from the sale of his animals, Alejandro is able to provide for his personal needs. In addition, he has another business preparing food for all types of events.

He is requesting a loan from Edpyme Alternativa in the amount of 2000 PEN so that he can buy more animals, the appropriate feed, and utensils for preparing food whenever anyone requests his services. Alejandro is known in the area for the good service he provides to his customers. He is a hardworking and dedicated person who puts forth much effort into his work so that he can get ahead.

loans.use: to purchase animals, appropriate feed, and utensils for his food business.

loans.name: Jayette

texts.en:
Jayette is 26 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with three children. Jayette provides motorcycle, or habal-habal, services with her husband as the driver. She has had this business for five years. She requested a loan of 5,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) to buy tools and pay for the maintenance of the service. 

Jayette is a new member of HSPFI. In the future, Jayette hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy tools and pay for the maintenance of her service

loans.name: Betsabe Cecilia

texts.es:
La señora Betsabe Cecilia Vive en la ciudad de Managua trabaja como oficinista en una empresa de Managua  es una persona responsable con dos personas menores a cargo de ella.

La señora Betsabe Cecilia  visito  nuestra oficina para solicitar un crédito para hacer  mejoras en su vivienda ya que con  la venida del invierno necesita cambiar el techo de la vivienda. el dinero que le presto ceprodel va a comprar zinc , madera ,y mano de obra .
Nuestra cliente  se siente agradecida por la oportunidad que ceprodel le brindo para mejorar su vivienda
texts.en:
Betsabe Cecilia lives in the city of Managua.  She is an office worker at a business in Managua.  She is a responsible person who cares for two young children.

Betsabe Cecilia visited our office to ask for a loan to make improvements to her home.  Since winter is coming, she needs to replace the roof of her house.  The money she borrows from Ceprodel will purchase zinc, wood, and labor.  

Our client is grateful for the opportunity that Ceprodel has given her to improve her home.

loans.use: to purchase construction materials.

loans.name: Margarette Ann

texts.en:
Margarette Ann is single and has a sari-sari store business in the Philippines. She has been in this business for 2 years.
Margarette Ann works hard to support her family.

Margarette Ann has requested a PHP 12,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more stock to sell.

In the future, Margarette Ann would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more stock to sell

loans.name: Titus

texts.en:
Titus is 41 years old, married, and has three children aged between ten and three years old. He describes himself as business-minded.

For the past fifteen years Titus has run a hardware business in Mombasa. He says his business is profitable with the only major challenge being insufficient capital.

Titus is using his loan of 50,000 KES to buy spare auto parts to sell to his customers. He hopes to grow his business into a wholesale enterprise. In the future, he sees himself diversifying into real estate, educating his children and building a house for his family.

loans.use: to buy spare auto parts to sell.

loans.name: Peace And Unity Group

texts.en:
Cecilia is the leader of this group of entrepreneurs. Cecilia was born in Makeni city about 49 years ago.  She is married to a public worker and the couple has 5 children, 3 of whom are attending primary and secondary schools. 

For 15 years now, Cecilia has been selling cotton cloths, gara lappers (locally dyed cloths), and shoes. With the help of this loan, these entrepreneurs will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and consequently improve on their living conditions. 

Cecilia will use her share of the loan (SLL 1,200,000) to expand her business.  She will buy cotton cloths and a dozen pairs of shoes to add to her business.

loans.use: buy cloths and shoes to resell

loans.name: Elmer

texts.en:
Elmer is married and the father of a school-aged child. He settles for a living in Aurora, Zamboanga del Sur, Philippines. He has been a fish vendor for over two years, selling different fish varieties every day to nearby communities to earn for the family. At the end of the month, Elmer earns about PHP 4,500, which he divides equally.

This year, Elmer became an official member of GDMPC. He has requested a loan of PHP 5,000 to order fish varieties to sell in the local community. He expects to have enough supply for the business, and to allocate an adequate sum of money to sustain his livelihood and expand his business range.

loans.use: To order fish varieties to sell in the local community.

loans.name: Reyna Carolina

texts.es: Reyna Carolina de cuarenta y uno años de edad vive con su compañero de vida y sus hijos en casa propia, en una populosa zona del país. Ella posee un taller de confección, diseña toda clase de ropa para niños, damas y caballeros,  como camisas, pantalones, faldas, vestidos o cualquiera otra prenda que soliciten que confecccione. Tiene muchos clientes por la calidad de su trabajo y porque siempre satisface los gustos de las personas, los precios son accesibles y el servicio excelente; Reyna es muy trabajadora siempre se encuentra adelante de su competencia, para ella todos tenemos la capacidad de alcanzar nuestros sueños y la felicidad, quiere un futuro de muchos éxitos y está trabajando duro para lograrlo es por eso que le solicita a INTEGRAL un crédito que le permita comprar telas por mayor, para seguir produciendo y satisfaciendo la necesidad de su clientela. Reyna Carolina tiene la esperanza de que con su esfuerzo logrará darle a su familia una mejor calidad de vida.
texts.en:
41-year old Reyna Carolina lives with her partner and their children in their own home in a highly populated part of the country. She owns a sewing business and designs all types of clothing for men, women and children such as shirts, pants, skirts, and dresses--whatever her customers order. She has many customers because of the quality of her work and because she always satisfies the tastes of her customers. As well, her prices are good and her service is excellent.

Reyna is a hardworking person and always ahead of the competition. In her view we all have the ability to fulfill our dreams and become happy. She wishes for a future filled with success and works hard to achieve this. For this reason she is seeking a loan from INTEGRAL which will allow her to buy more material at wholesale prices so she can continue making clothing and satisfying the needs of her customers. Reyna Carolina hopes that her efforts will succeed in providing her family with a better quality of life.

loans.use: to buy material at wholesale prices

loans.name: Nelia

texts.en:
Nelia is 49 years old and married with six children. She lives in the Philippines. For the past five years, Nelia has run a retail shop where she sells canned goods, snacks, and beverages. She is a new HSPFI member.

Nelia is requesting a 5,000 PHP loan to buy canned goods, snacks and beverages to sell. In the future, she hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks, and  beverages

loans.name: Deggo De Seguel Group

texts.fr: Deggo de seguel est un groupement constitué de 5 femmes. Elles habitent dans la même localité et leur activité principale est le commerce. Deggo est représenté par Madame Astou qui évolue dans le secteur du commerce de fruits (clémentine )  depuis plus de 15 ans. Elle est mariée et mère de 7 enfants. Elle est est membre de l'un des guichets de l'U-IMCEC et sollicite un crédit de 250 000 prévu pour l'achat de fruits  qui seront destinés a la vente. L'objectif recherché est le développement de son son activité de commerce ainsi que celui des membres respectifs du groupe. Elle souhaite accroitre ses revenus et améliorer les conditions de vie sociale de sa famille en soutenant son mari dans la gestion des dépenses quotidiennes du foyer.
texts.en: This group is made up of five women. They live in the same town and their principal activity is sales. Deggo is represented by Madame Astou, who has been in the fruit-selling business (clementines) for the past 15 years. She is married and the mother of 7 children. She is a member of one of UIMCEC's branches, and is asking for a loan of 250,000 francs in order to buy fruit to resell. Her objective is to grow her business as well as the business of the other members of her group. She hopes to increase her revenues and improve the living conditions of her family by supporting her husband in the management of day-to-day household costs.

loans.use: To purchase fruit for resale

loans.name: Ana Maria

texts.es: Ana María se dedica a la venta de cosa de horno, desde hace más de 27 años que tiene este negocio. Consiste en la elaboración de cosa de horno que ofrece de manera ambulante a pesar que no ha sido fácil pues tiene ciertas dificultades como la falta de capital de trabajo para ofrecer a sus clientes. El motivo del crédito es para la compra de maíz, leche, queso, azúcar, harina, arroz, bolsas, entre otros productos. Sueña con mejorar sus ingresos y además de esto ampliar cada día su negocio.
texts.en: Ana María has worked selling corn-based breads for more than 27 years.  She makes the bread and then sells it on the streets.  This business has not been easy for her, and she struggles with certain difficulties, like a lack of capital to make enough products to offer to her customers.  Her goal with this loan is to buy corn, milk, cheese, sugar, flour, rice, bags, and other products.  She dreams of increasing her earnings and, in addition to this, dreams of expanding her business each day.

loans.use: buy corn, milk, cheese, sugar, flour, rice, bags, and other products

loans.name: Nderagakura Group

texts.fr:
Mathias est un commerçant âgé de 39ans qui habite la localité de Kwibuka de la Province de Gitega au centre du pays. Il fait le commerce d’articles divers (haricots, souliers, riz, savons, huile, souliers…) dans son kiosque depuis 10 ans. Il a commence cette activité lorsqu’il travaillait pour un autre commerçant. Il a fait ses études jusqu’en 6e année primaire. Il est marie a Beatrice, une cultivatrice et ont ensemble 5 enfants dont 4 étudient a l’école primaire. 
 Le crédit Kiva  de 250,000 francs burundais qu’il obtient lui permet d’augmenter son capital pour acheter de grandes quantités d’articles divers (haricots, souliers, riz, savons, huile, souliers…)  pour son kiosque à revendre  afin de réaliser de grands bénéfices. 

Il est membre  du groupe  communautaire« NDERAGAKURA»
texts.en:
Mathias is a businessman aged 39 who lives in Kwibuka in the province of Gitega in the center of the country. He has been selling various items (beans, shoes, rice soap, oil, etc.) in his stall for 10 years. He began this activity when he was working for another businessman. He attended school up to 6th grade. He is married to Beatrice, a farmer, and together they have five children of whom four are enrolled in primary school. 

The Kiva loan of 250,000 Burundi francs that he will receive will allow him to grow his working capital so as to buy big quantities of various items (beans, shoes, rice, soap, oil, etc.) for his stall so as to make a lot of profit. 

He is a member of the group called "NDERAGAKURA".

loans.use: to grow his working capital so that he can buy large quantities of various items (beans, shoes, rice, soap, oil) to sell in his stall.

loans.name: Esther

texts.es:
Esther es socia del Banco Comunal Properidad, tiene 60 años, es casada, madre de 3 hijos, estuvo en Finca por 15 años y por problemas de salud se retiro, hace 6 meses volvió a reincorporarse como socia.
Esther tiene una tienda de Abarrotes, con los préstamos que ha recibido, logró pagar sus deudas, hubo un tiempo en que ella tenia muchos problemas pero lo supero y logró salir adelante, le gusta las capacitaciones porque le enseña ahorrar, a dirigir su negocio y sobre todo a no sobreendeudarse.
el préstamo que solicita lo invertirá en la compra de abarrotes tales como azúcar, arroz, gaseosas.
Su meta es seguir creciendo con su negocio hasta lograr que sus hijos sean profesionales.
texts.en:
Esther is a member of the Prosperity Communal Bank; she is 60 years old, married and a mother to 3 children. She was in Finca (Kiva's field partner) for 15 years and for health reasons she retired and 6 months ago she reincorporated herself as a member.

Esther has a small grocery store and with loans she was able to pay her debts and for some time had many problems but was able to overcome them and get ahead. Esther enjoys her communal bank because it has taught her to save, manage her business and above all to not over indebt herself.

The loan that she is asking for will be used to buy groceries like sugar, rice and beverages.

Esther’s goal is to keep her business growing and to have her children become professionals.

loans.use: buy sugar, rice and beverages.

loans.name: Wendy Marlen

texts.es: Wendy es una mujer muy trabajadora y es muy activa con lo que hace. Hace un año inicio con su propio negocio de hot dogs, nachos, hamburguesas al carbón y papas francesas  que ofrece en su colonia y su esposo en una moto reparte de casa en casa. Wendy comenzó con el negocio viendo que su economía familiar estaba muy baja y algunas veces no tenia para comer, ya que su esposo fue liquidado de una empresa y por la edad no ha podido conseguir un buen trabajo, de esta forma fue que se dio a la tarea de trabajar en negocio donde tuviera sus propias ganancias, ser dueña, apoyar a su esposo con los gastos y trabajar juntos para prosperar. La señora Wendy da un buen servicio en su negocio esta creciendo y tiene mas clientela algunas ocasiones no completa  con su mercancía por tal motivo quiere comprar mas materia prima como pan de hot dogs, hamburguesas, carne, salchicha, nachos y queso para abastecer los pedidos.
texts.en:
Wendy is a hard-working woman who puts a lot of energy into what she does.  A year ago she started her own business of selling hot dogs, nachos, grilled hamburgers, and French fries in her neighborhood, and  her husband also delivers them house to house on his motorbike.  Wendy started the business when she saw that the family’s finances were poor and sometime there was not enough food to eat.  This happened because her husband was let go from a company and because of his age, was not able to find a good job.  Thus she took on the task of working in a business where she would make her own money, be her own boss, support her husband with the expenses, and allow them to work together to prosper.  

Wendy gives good service to her customers in the business and it is growing.  Sometimes, however, she has more customers than she has product, so that is why she wants to buy more basic supplies such as hot dog rolls, hamburgers, meat, sausages, nachos and cheese to fill the orders.

loans.use: to buy bread, sausages, and meat for her business

loans.name: Mary Chriz

texts.en: Mary Chriz is 28 years old, married and the mother of two children. She lives in Baliangao, Misamis Occidental, where she has earned a living for the last five years by selling seafood. She makes PHP 2,800 a month and is applying for a loan for PHP 4,000 to buy new fishing equipment, including hooks and nets. She joined GDMPC a year ago as a way to improve her family's living conditions.

loans.use: to buy fishing equipment.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy cables and computer parts to do his work assembling computers.

loans.name: Lauro

texts.es: Lauro de 62 años, vive en su propia casa junto a su esposa Tomasa de 65 años y sus 03 queridos hijos a quienes desea ofrecerles una mejor calidad de vida. Para Lauro, la vida es un regalo, ya que le ha brindado muchos caminos por elegir. Ahora él se dedica por entero al cultivo de cacao, en donde le esta yendo de la mejor manera y se siente contento con el trabajo que está realizando. Regularmente recibe la ayuda de su familia, pero por lo general en temporada de cosecha tiene a cargo de sus peones, para que le puedan agilizar la extracción de su producto de forma eficiente y eficaz. Normalmente su producto los vende en los centros de acopio de su comunidad. En el futuro anhela extender su chacra en grandes hectáreas, con el propósito de que produzca en grandes producciones y de mayor calidad. Este será su crédito número 03 con MFP, por lo que se compromete en cumplir fielmente con sus respectivos pagos. Además agradece la confianza que le está otorgando su grupo comunal. Con los 3,000 nuevos soles, lo invertirá en el mantenimiento continuo de su sus plantaciones de cacao; comprando fertilizantes y contratando personal para que lo ayuden a sacar la maleza de sus plantaciones.
texts.en:
Lauro, 62, lives in his own house along with his wife Tomasa, 65, and their three beloved children, whom he wants to offer a better quality of life.  For Lauro, life is a gift because it has offered him many roads from which to choose.

Now he devotes himself completely to growing cacao, which is going in the best possible way for him, and he feels happy about the job he is doing.  He regularly receives help from his family, but generally at harvest time he has day laborers who can help him speed up the harvest of his product efficiently and effectively.  Normally he sells his product in the distribution centers in his community.  In the future he hopes to expand his farm into large hectares, with the goal of producing harvests that are bigger and of better quality.

This will be his third loan with MFP, and he is committed to making his respective payments faithfully.  He also is grateful for the trust that his communal bank is giving him.

With the 3,000 PEN he will invest in ongoing maintenance of his cacao fields, buying fertilizers and hiring personnel to help him weed his fields.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and hire day laborers.

loans.name: Allah Thantho Group

texts.en:
Meet with members of the “Allah Thantho” group from Kabala, a town in northern Sierra Leone. They are all local entrepreneurs who have come to SMT, a partner of Kiva, to apply for a loan of 500,000 Sierra Leonean Leones (SLL)  for each. With the help of this loan they will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and consequently improve their living conditions. 

Marie is the leader of this group. The thirty-two-year-old is married to a retired worker and they have three children. Marie has been a businesswoman for six years now. She sells plastic bowls, plates, buckets, spoons, and ready-to-wear-clothes.  With her share of this loan, she will buy the above mentioned items at wholesale prices to add to her current stock.

loans.use: to buy plastic bowls, plates, buckets, spoons, and ready-to-wear-clothes at wholesale prices.

loans.name: Pierrette

texts.fr:
Pierrette  est une femme travailleuse et active de 33 ans. Elle est mariée et le couple exerce ensemble les activités source de revenu familial. C'est à dire le mari l’aide dans ses activités. Le nombre d’enfants est de quatre, ils sont âges de 13,10,7 et 3 ans, tous scolarisés dans des écoles privées . 
L’activité de gargote exercée depuis des années  est encore sa principale source de revenus.  Cette activité a été complétée par la vente de sandales en plastiques devant la gargote. Ce sont les activités sources de revenus du couple.  Pierrette  s’occupe de la gargote, le mari se charge de la vente de sandales et de l'approvisionnement. 
Le couple a comme principal souci l’éducation de leurs enfants. Le couple prévoit de construire une maison afin d’éviter de payer loyer durant long temps.
texts.en:
Pierrette is a hardworking, active woman of 33. She is married and the couple work together at earning the family income, that is, her husband helps her with her businesses. They have four children aged 13, 10, 7, and three years old. All are attending private schools.

The snack bar they have had for years is their primary source of income. This business is supplemented by selling sandals made of plastic outside the snack bar. These are the income sources of the couple. Pierrette takes care of the snack bar and her husband takes care of the sale of sandals and supplying the snack bar.

The couple's principal worry is their children's education. They are planning to build a house so as to avoid paying rent for a long period.

loans.use: to buy vegetables (carrots, potatoes, pasta, oil, eggs) and plastic sandals.

loans.name: Alberto

texts.en:
Alberto is 45 years old, he has 3 very young children and they are studying. His family is the most important thing in his life, for that reason, every day he works very hard to offer them an education and a home. Alberto wants to build a house where his children can live, at the moment his family lives in a very small room and their resources are limited. He and his family live in Pedro Escobedo Querétaro and together with his wife; they work to cover their family expenses. Alberto was born in Acapulco Guerrero and he started his small business selling special sea food like fish and shellfish.

He requires a loan of $475 USD to purchase merchandise, as fresh fish, shellfish and shrimp. Alberto and his family require of your help to continue working and continue building their house. In a term of 6 months Alberto plans to return the loan.

** This text has been translated from the following original business description.

Alberto tiene 45 años de edad, tiene 3 hijos muy jóvenes y se encuentran estudiando. Su familia es lo más importante en su vida, por lo que todos los días trabaja muy duro para ofrecerles una educación y un hogar. Alberto quiere construir una casa donde sus hijos puedan vivir, actualmente vive toda su familia en un cuarto muy pequeño y sus recursos son muy limitados. El y su familia viven en Pedro Escobedo Querétaro y junto con su esposa, trabajan para cubrir los gastos del hogar. Alberto nació en Acapulco Guerrero e inició su pequeño negocio vendiendo platillos de la costa, como los son los mariscos.

El requiere un préstamo de $475 USD para comprar insumos, como pescado fresco, mariscos y camarón. Alberto y su familia requieren de tu ayuda para seguir trabajando y continuar construyendo su casa. En un término de 6 meses Alberto planea regresar el préstamo.

loans.use: Purchase merchandise, as fresh fish, shellfish and shrimp.

loans.name: Yao

texts.en:
Born on January 31, 1975 in Aného in the Lakes region, Mr. Yao A. is a devoted, dynamic and very intelligent young man. Because of his parent's lack of means, he had to leave his studies to start a business in Lomé.

Today, he is married and a father of a child with another dependant, and his wife is a housewife. He is able to provide for his family's needs by selling poplin fabric. Although he has a very average level of edication, he has an entrepreneurial spirit and has been able to successfully manage and refund credits previously given to him. To this end, he is asking for a $900 loan to purchase supplies for his business. The benefits from this financing will be used to improve his family's living conditions.

Translated from French by Ivana Kostic, Kiva Volunteer.

Né le 31 janvier 1975 à Aného dans la préfecture des Lacs, Monsieur A. Yao est un jeune homme dévoué, dynamique et très intelligent. Par manque de moyens de la part de ses parents, il a dû abandonner ses études pour se lancer dans le commerce à Lomé. Aujourd’hui, père de famille avec un enfant et une autre personne à charge, sa femme est ménagère. Il subvient aux besoins de la famille par les bénéfices tirés de la vente de tissus popeline en détails. Avec un niveau d’étude très moyen, il a un esprit d’entreprenariat et une capacité de gérer un crédit et de le rembourser. A cet effet, il sollicite, un crédit de $900 pour s’approvisionner en gros. Les bénéfices qui découleront du financement de ses activités commerciales serviront à améliorer ses conditions de vie et celles de sa famille.

loans.use: Poplin fabric sales

loans.name: Mohammad Qasam

texts.en: Mohammad Qasam lives in district 6 of Kabul ,Afghanistan. He is uneducated but he has good working experience. He was very small when he started carpet weaving and he has  lots of students. He wants to take a individual loan to expand his business and buy 3 more looms and the other materials necessary for weaving. He hopes that he can further this business and he can compete with other carpet weavers and export carpets to other places. He wants to thank AFSG for helping him.

loans.use: To buy 3 carpet weaving machines and other materials

loans.name: Heng

texts.en: Mrs. Heng S. is 28 years old and lives in Kampong Cham, Cambodia with her husband and their two children.  Mrs Heng S. sells mangoes to the people in her village, while her husband works as a construction foreman.  Combined, their income is around $4/day.  She is seeking this loan in order to purchase a wood frame and construction materials to build a small cart for selling her mangoes.  She believes this new cart will help her to expand her sales area and also her daily income.  In the future, she hopes to continue expanding her business in order to meet her clients' demand.

loans.use: To purchase wood frame to hang mangoes for her business

loans.name: Tafaoga

texts.en: Tafaoga F. is  25-year old  mother of 2 who runs a fishing business. She joined SPBD six months ago when seeking financial support to start her business. She has now got a business that is running well with great support from her husband and relatives. Tafaoga has never had any experience in fishing, but learned a lot from her husband, and is very interested in her business now. Both her and her husband are otherwise unemployed, and their business is what they’ll be concentrating on in order to save up some money to send their two kids to school. Neither of them got a chance to graduate from school due to lack of support from their families, and it’s a problem that they want to overcome, so it does not happen to their children. Tafaoga aims to stay longer in the programme and maintain her business for a better future for her family.

loans.use: Loan will be used to purchase new fishing gear

loans.name: Daría

texts.es:
Daria, 39 years old, is from the province of Huaraz and is a member of the Banco Comunal Paltainas al Progreso. She has two children, a 16 year-old who is a student and a second child with Downs Syndrome. Daria dedicates herself to the sale of flowers and melocotones (fruit). She sells her flowers in a market located in the District of Caraz, and her clients take them as far as Trujillo. Her fruit sales take place at a stand she has in a market located in the District of Carhuaz. With a recent loan of 500.00 soles (approx. $167USD) from Manuela Ramos, which will be paid in four monthly installments, she hopes to purchase fertilizer and other treatments for her flower and fruit crops.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Daría tiene 39 años de edad, es del Centro Poblado de Paltay, del Distrito Taricá, Provincia de Huaraz. Es socia fundadora del Banco Comunal Paltainas al Progreso, tiene 2 hijos, el primero tiene 16 años y estudia en la academia y el segundo tiene síndrome de Down. La señora Daría se dedica a la venta de Flores y a la venta de melocotones (fruta), la venta de flores lo realiza en el mercado del Distrito de Caraz, cuenta con clientes que las llevan hasta Trujillo, y la venta de Melocotones lo hace en el puesto que tiene en un mercado en el Distrito de Carhuaz. Con el reciente préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/. 500.00 soles ($ 167.00 aprox.) el cual será pagado en 4 cuotas, comprará abono y remedios, fertilizantes para flores y Melocotones.

loans.use: Purchase fertilizer for fruit and flower crops.

loans.name: Alice Adu

texts.en:
Alice Adu – G. is a trader at Moree Junction. She sells fante kenkey, a popular Ghanaian food, sweet potatoes, and body creams. She has seven children. She is a hardworking woman. In order to take very good care of her family, she also travels to the northern part of the country to buy maize, groundnuts, and yams to supply them to her customers in and around Cape Coast. She is well-known as a supplier of maize and groundnuts. Occasionally, she also sells body creams and lotions.

One major challenge Alice faces is that she has received lots of orders from her customers for the supply of maize, yams and groundnuts, but the prices of these foodstuffs are relatively lower in the northern part of Ghana than the south. Alice is therefore asking for a loan of US $800 to enable her to travel to the north to buy the foodstuffs (maize, yam, groundnuts, and sweet potatoes) to supply to her customers.

loans.use: To travel to the north to buy the foodstuffs (maize, yam, groundnuts, and sweet potatoes) to supply to her customers.

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en:
Mambo from Dar es Salaam! This is 55-year-old Lucy M.. She is married with five children, ages between 19 and 37, and has two other dependents who are her nieces.
 
Lucy owns a poultry business and has already received and successfully repaid one loan from SELFINA. She now requests a loan of $525 in order to purchase additional chickens and expand their enclosure. She thanks you for your support.

Raising kuku is a popular micro-business in Tanzania, especially amongst SELFINA clients. In fact, if you are a regular lender on kiva.org, you may be tired of reading about kuku! "Who or what are kuku?" you may ask. Kuku means chickens in Swahili, and raising them for sale is popular for a number of reasons. 

First, they require little start-up capital. You can start with one or two and either add to them as you go or wait for them to multiple naturally. Second, they require little space, so sometimes you can just let them run around in your garden or compound. Third, while they are growing they produce eggs, which can either be sold to provide a supplementary source of income or eaten to provide a supplementary source of protein. I’m sure there are hundreds of other reasons why raising kuku is so popular (maybe they are friendlier than other animals? Prettier?), but this is all time and space will allow.

loans.use: To purchase additional chicks and expand their enclosure (their vet has pronounced that they are suffering from stress from overcrowding).

loans.name: Saida

texts.en:
C. Saida is 49 years old. She is married with one son. Their son is already married and his children adore their grandparents.

Saida sells women’s knitted jackets in the local market. She started her business 15 years ago. Her husband, an entrepreneur, provided the funds for start-up. Gradually Saida's business expanded. Being hard-working and polite by her nature she managed to attract the clients who are happy with her goods and services. The business generates stable income for the family.

Saida requests 600 USD for the term of 3 months. She is planning to spend the loan to purchase new knitted jackets for inventory. Saida is a repeat client for IMON. She managed all the previous loans accurately without violations. She thanks everyone for their support and promises to pay this loan in a timely manner.

loans.use: To purchase knitted jackets to sell

loans.name: Salelologa P Centre - Group 1

texts.en: The members of Salelologa P are women who have stalls in the marketplace of the Salelologa village on Savaii Island.  Most of them have been in this kind of business for several years.  The reason they joined the SPBD program is not only to receive loans for their flourishing businesses but also to learn new things about managing their businesses and saving.  Their stalls in the market are near SPBD's office, so it was easy for them to get information about the program when they first started.  Now, they meet every Thursday to discuss their ideas and support each other.

loans.use: to purchase additional commodities to sell in their market stalls

loans.name: Fahriddin

texts.ru:
Fahriddin A. lives in the town of Yavan. He is 32 years old, married and has three children. He has no formal education. He does animal husbandry and breeds large cattle to be able to feed his family. He has a small cow house where he keeps the calves and then sells them on the market where he buys younger ones. He has been in this business for the past three years. Fahriddin wants to get a loan and use it to increase his cattle head count. It will bring additional income to him. His not so big but joyful family also try to help Fahriddin with this business. He plans to pay off the loan within 9 months.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer.

Азизов Фахриддин проживает в городе Яван. Женат и имеет 3 детей . Клиенту 32 года, но он не имеет образования. Для того , чтобы прокормить семью клиент занимается разведением крупно рогатого скота. У него есть небольшое хозяйство в котором он разводит бычков . Потом он продает их на базаре и покупает новых помоложе. Занимается этим видом бизнеса клиент уже 3 года.Клиент хочет получить кредит и использовать его для того чтобы увеличить поголовье скота. Это поможет клиенту получить дополнительный доход. У него небольшая и веселая семья и они все вместе стараются помочь Фахриддину. Погасить кредит клиенгт планирует в течении 9 месяцев.

loans.use: To buy calves

loans.name: Mankagno

texts.fr:
Mankagno D., 51 years old and married with 10 children in her care, is the president at the heart of the steering committee of the village bank of Kandé Banéto in Ziguinchor. She buys bananas in Balantacounda, an area renowned for the cultivation and sale of bananas, and then sells them in Ziguinchor. Mankagno has been running this business for five years and has always respected her financial arrangements. Her income allows her to participate in supporting her family. She is asking for a loan which will be reimbursed at the end of six months in one single payment.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

Mankagno D., 51 ans, mariée, 10 enfants en charge est présidente au sein du comité de gestion du banc villageois de Kandé Banéto à Ziguinchor.
